DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that China will double the purchases of agricultural goods from the US under the Phase One pact and that the US-China signing will be in the middle of January. Furthermore, Mnuchin added that the trade agreement is not open to renegotiation and suggested the USMCA trade pact should add 0.5pp to US GDP. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry hopes the US and China proactively seeks effective solutions regarding the building of trust and to resolve disagreements, while it has also commented that China and the US are to maintain communication regarding the Korean Peninsula. (Newswires)

  • New Zealand ANZ Consumer Confidence Index (Dec) 123.3 (Prev. 120.7). (Newswires)
  • New Zealand ANZ Consumer Confidence (Dec) M/M 2.2% (Prev. 1.9%)

 

UK/EU

UK BOE Bank Rate (Dec) 0.75% vs. Exp. 0.75% (Prev. 0.75%). MPC voted 7-2 to stand pat on rates at 0.75%, while it voted 9-0 to maintain the stock of UK government bond purchases at GBP 435bln and to maintain the stock of corporate bonds at GBP 10bln. MPC reiterated that monetary policy could respond in either direction in order to hit its inflation target in which monetary policy could be required if global growth fails to stabilise and Brexit uncertainties remain entrenched. However, it added that should these risks not materialise and the economy performs broadly in-line with the MPC’s projection, gradual and limited rate rises could be needed. (Newswires)

There were initial reports that FCA Chief Executive Andrew Bailey was emerging as the favourite for the new Bank of England Governor to replace Mark Carney at the end of January, while reports later stated that Bailey was selected for the BoE Governor position. (FT)

EU Economic Commissioner Gentiloni said EZ could be stuck at 1% economic growth for longer unless it acts and that EU should create a true financial union to complete EZ integration. (Newswires)

EU Council President Michel said the bloc will make deeper ties with China a priority in 2020, whilst not letting US dictate the bloc's approach to China. (WSJ)

  • UK Retail Sales MM (Nov) -0.6% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)
  • UK Retail Sales YY (Nov) 1.0% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 3.1%)

 

FX

Mexican Interest Rate (Dec) 7.25% vs. Exp. 7.25% (Prev. 7.50%), although the decision was not unanimous as one member voted for a 50bps cut, while it stated that the current environment continues to present risks that could affect the macroeconomic conditions in the country and its potential for growth. (Newswires) 

 

US

Fed's Bullard (Voter, Dove) said he has pencilled in no rate increases for 2020 and reiterated that the Fed should be data dependent. Bullard added he would want to see more inflation before he would call for a rate increase and said he is not putting a lot of weight on the idea that inflation is going to be particularly high anytime soon. (WSJ)

US House voted 385 vs. 41 to approve the USMCA trade agreement, while there were separate reports that the Senate passed the second of the FY20 spending bills to avert a government shutdown. (Newswires)

  • US Existing Home Sales % Change (Nov) -1.7% vs. Exp. -0.2% (Prev. 1.9%, Rev. 1.5%). (Newswires)
  • US Initial Jobless Claims w/e 234k vs. Exp. 225.0k (Prev. 252.0k)
  • US Philly Fed Business Index (Dec) 0.3 vs. Exp. 8.0 (Prev. 10.4)

 

MARKET RECAP

US equity bourses found new highs on Thursday – SPX exceeding 3200 for the first time – as the “Santa/Christmas/Holiday rally” continued, supporting the energy complex, too; however, the majority of the gains emerged in the early part of the session with markets remaining in lido through till the close in what was a news light session. As the stock market found its limits, the havens – Treasuries, XAU and JPY – found their strength into the afternoon, desks note that with expectations of depleting liquidity heading into next week and year-end, there is likely to be elements of book squaring/position closing, causing investors to take advantage of any volatility; note the VIX is acutely low, sitting just above 12. Micron (MU) were firmer after its earnings which were in line and guided lower than expected for Q2, however the co. signalled a bottoming out of its financial performance in Q2, whilst its 8-k filing also removed the mention of it being mindful of macroeconomic and trade uncertainties. LiveNation (LYV) surged almost 10% after source reports stated that it reached a tentative agreement with the Department of Justice over its antitrust concerns; the story was later confirmed by LYV. Centene (CNC) and Molina Health (MOH) were higher after The Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the ruling that the Affordable Care Act’s individual mandate is unconstitutional but sent the case back to reconsider; Oppenheimer stated the ACA isn’t going anywhere soon, and JP Morgan highlighted the two companies hold the greatest exposure to the ACA. Roku (ROKU) were higher after a positive mention at Motley Fool, and Dropbox (DBX) reportedly saw a positive mention from Gordon Haskett. General Motors (GM) initially opened lower but ended the day relatively flat after it announced it is to recall ~900k vehicles, while Uber (UBER) had its rental car services in Germany banned by a Frankfurt court, which stated that the ride hailing company is lacking a license to offer passengers transport services via rental car providers. SPX +0.5% at 3205, NDX +0.7% at 8887, DJ +0.5% at 28377.

The T-Note sold off in the earlier session, catching momentum as US participants came to their desks, although the losses were reversed heading into the close, leaving the T-Note slightly firmer, with yields falling most pronounced in the belly, by approximately 2bps. Desks note that as liquidity begins to thin, desks will be eager to close positions and take advantage of any large moves, with this Friday likely serving as a last chance before Christmas for many. Thursday’s reversal of the move higher in yields could potentially be technically driven as the 2s10s flirted with 30bps earlier on, perhaps the misses in the Philly Fed Index and US housing starts tamed the Treasury sell off somewhat, too, whilst some desks attributed participants ceasing the low prices before the weekend. T-notes (H0) futures settled 4+ ticks higher at 128-10.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 19th December 2019: Holiday rally sees SPX breach 3200
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Mnuchin says Phase One to be signed in January, BoE, BoJ, Norges stand pat whilst Riksbank hike and Banxico cut
  • COMING UP: Data: US GDP, PCE & Final UoM, Baker Hughes Rig Count, UK GDP, Canadian Retail Sales, EZ Consumer Confidence. Speakers: BoE’s Haskel. NOTE: Heavy FX OpEx and Quad-witching

* MARKETS WRAP: US equity bourses found new highs on Thursday – SPX exceeding 3200 for the first time – as the “Santa/Christmas/Holiday rally” continued, supporting the energy complex, too; however, the majority of the gains emerged in the early part of the session with markets remaining in lido through till the close in what was a news light session. As the stock market found its limits, the havens – Treasuries, XAU and JPY – found their strength into the afternoon, desks note that with expectations of depleting liquidity heading into next week and year-end, there is likely to be elements of book squaring/position closing, causing investors to take advantage of any volatility; note the VIX is acutely low, sitting just above 12. The over-arching themes remain risk supportive, Phase One looks ready to be signed in January (something US Treasury Sec. Mnuchin stressed on Thursday), the strong November NFP report abated near-term employment concerns for the US consumer (read: powerhouse), whilst the holiday season historically points to further upside in thinner trade as portfolio managers call it a year. There was a slew of central bank rate decisions on Thursday, BoE stood pat with two dovish dissenters, as expected; Riksbank hiked, but evidence of a one-and-done saw some weakness in the SEK upon release; BoJ and Norges were mainly non-events, with the latter’s currency firming after no outlook downgrades; Banxico cut by 25bps as was expected. US data was less inspiring, where existing home sales for November missed expectations with the prior revised lower, although the outlook remains favourable; the Philly Fed survey for December missed expectations in the headline, but the forward-looking New Orders sub-index picked up slightly. Looking ahead, NKE reports after the bell, followed on Friday by US GDP, PCE and the final University of Michigan (Dec), with many likely thereafter throwing in the towel before Christmas.

* US TREASURY SECRETARY MNUCHIN said that China will double the purchases of agricultural goods from the US under the Phase One pact, adding that the US-China signing will be the middle of January, in line with previous US official commentary. Mnuchin stressed that the trade pact is not open to renegotiation. Elsewhere, the Treasury Sec. said the USMCA trade pact should add 0.5pp to US GDP, also that the strength of the USD is a sign of the strength of the US economy.

* FED: Fed's Bullard (non-voter, dove) said he has pencilled in no rate increases for 2020, and reiterates that the Fed should be data dependence, the WSJ reported. Like other Fed members, the St. Louis President said he would want to see more inflation before he would call for rate hikes, “I’m not putting a lot of weight” on the idea that inflation is going to be particularly high anytime soon.

* BOE: Policymakers once again opted to stand pat on rates at 0.75% with a 7-2 vote split as Saunders and Haskel remained as dissenters to the decision. Overall, a majority of policymakers opted to refrain from policy action on the basis that economic data since the November meeting had been broadly as expected and it was too early to judge how recent global and domestic policy announcements would impact the economic outlook. Saunders and Haskel voted in favour of a 25bps rate reduction given their assessment that the economy had actually performed a little softer than expected, whilst raising concerns over subdued core inflation and slowing employment growth; an argument that was unable to convince Vlieghe to switch camps despite some outside bets for him to do so. In terms of the overall tone of the statement, the MPC refrained from making any policy inferences from last week’s election outcome and instead reiterated their assumption that there will be an orderly transition to a deep free trade agreement between the UK and the EU. Furthermore, the MPC reiterated that monetary policy could respond in either direction in order to hit its inflation target. Additionally, looser monetary policy could be required if global growth fails to stabilise and Brexit uncertainties remain entrenched. However, should these risks not materialise and the economy performs broadly in-line with the MPC’s projection, gradual and limited rate rises could be needed. In terms of the outlook for the UK economy, the Bank looks for just 0.1% growth in Q4 and reiterated the likelihood of headline CPI falling to around 1.25% in the spring, owing to the temporary effects of falls in regulated energy and water prices. With regards to the labour market, policymakers noted some loosening, however it remains tight overall, adding that the unemployment rate remains stable and employment is around the record high. Overall, the BoE opted to conclude the year without much in the way of fanfare and broadly stuck to the “wait-and-see” message.

* US EXISTING HOME SALES (NOV) fell by 1.7% to 5.35mln from 5.44mln, missing the expected 5.44mln, with the prior revised lower from 5.46mln. Wells Fargo’s analysts look past the decline, which it attributes to a 1.2% fall in single-family sales and a 5.1% drop in condo sales, pointing to the 2.7% gain over the year, “Sales should continue to improve with support from low mortgage rates, although inventory shortages will limit the upside.” The bank notes that homes are selling on the market in an average 38 days, compared to 48 days in November 2018., a further nod to demand strength, although Wells caveat that exuberant upside is limited, with inventories down by 5.7% Y/Y, giving the lowest November reading since 1999.

* T-NOTE (H0) FUTURES SETTLED 4+ TICKS HIGHER AT 128-10. The T-Note sold off in the earlier session, catching momentum as US participants came to their desks, although the losses were reversed heading into the close, leaving the T-Note slightly firmer, with yields falling most pronounced in the belly, by approximately 2bps. Desks note that as liquidity begins to thin, desks will be eager to close positions and take advantage of any large moves, with this Friday likely serving as a last chance before Christmas for many. Thursday’s reversal of the move higher in yields could potentially be technically driven as the 2s10s flirted with 30bps earlier on, perhaps the misses in the Philly Fed Index and US housing starts tamed the Treasury sell off somewhat, too, whilst some desks attributed participants ceasing the low prices before the weekend.

* WTI (G0) SETTLES USD 0.33 HIGHER AT USD 61.18/BBL; BRENT (G0) SETTLES USD 0.37 HIGHER AT USD 66.54/BBL. The holiday optimism continued to support the energy complex, in addition to the equity market, helping oil benchmarks continue to make multi-month highs. Prices found their impetus as US participants, or those still present, came to their desks. There has been little in the way of energy-specific news flow since the bullish EIA report on Wednesday, where the seasonal risk appetite and OPEC+ supply cuts, in addition to the US-China Phase One progress, remain supportive to energy prices. Note that January WTI futures expire on Thursday.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.45% at 3205, NDX +0.67% at 8887, DJ +0.49% at 28377

* EARNINGS: Micron (MU) were firmer after its earnings which were in line and guided lower than expected for Q2, however the co. signalled a bottoming out of its financial performance in Q2, whilst its 8-k filing also removed the mention of it being mindful of macroeconomic and trade uncertainties. Conagra Brands (CAG) surged after a beat on EPS and revenues were in line with expectations, the co. also cut its FY20 EPS forecast, although the cut was not as deep as analysts were expecting. CAG also expect strong performance in H2 2020. Darden Restaurants (DRI) were lower after its Q2 SSS missed expectations printing 2.0%, 0.1% beneath expectations.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: LiveNation (LYV) surged almost 10% after source reports stated that it reached a tentative agreement with the Department of Justice over its antitrust concerns; the story was later confirmed by LYV. Centene (CNC) and Molina Health (MOH) were higher after The Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the ruling that the Affordable Care Act’s individual mandate is unconstitutional but sent the case back to reconsider; Oppenheimer stated the ACA isn’t going anywhere soon, and JP Morgan highlighted the two companies hold the greatest exposure to the ACA. Roku (ROKU) were higher after a positive mention at Motley Fool, and Dropbox (DBX) reportedly saw a positive mention from Gordon Haskett. General Motors (GM) initially opened lower but ended the day relatively flat after it announced it is to recall ~900k vehicles. Uber (UBER) had its Uber rental car services in Germany banned by a Frankfurt court, which stated that the ride hailing company is lacking a license to offer passengers transport services via rental car providers. Netflix (NFLX) were higher after a positive mention from Goldman, who maintained a conviction buy with a PT of USD 400, stating expectations for its subscriber growth and related financials in 2020 and beyond are too low. Goldman Sachs (GS) is reportedly in talks with the US government to pay a two-billion dollar fine, admit guild, and agree to an ongoing oversight of its compliance procedures to resolve the criminal investigation of the 1MDB probe, according to WSJ. Previous reports had stated that the fine is likely to be under USD 2bln. In the tail-end of the session, FBN’s Gasparino citing sources announced GS are to face billions more in settlements, on top of the initial one over the scandal.

* M&A: IAC (IAC) is to divest its shares in online dating service Match (MTCH). The information reported Facebook (FB) held talks to buy Cirrus Logic (CRUS) earlier in the year. PayPal (PYPL) announced it completed the acquisition of GoPay. Ecolab Inc. (ECL) is to separate its Upstream energy business of Nalco Champion and combine it with Apergy (APY) in a tax-free transaction.

* RIKSBANK: Riksbank hiked rates by 25bps as expected and as it had long been signalling. Opposition to the hike, however, was apparent with Jansson and Breman entering reservations. Preferring, instead of today’s decision, for the forecast period to indicate a hike in Q1 2020 or further. The repo rate forecasts indicate the rate will remain unchanged for 2020 and 2021, with just 10bp of upside indicated by 2022. The decision to hike in a ‘one and done’ move was as expected; the main surprise was the reservations from Breman as this was her first meeting and the comment that the Riksbank could, if it became necessary, make policy more expansionary through ‘other measures’ as well as cuts. Reaction was minimal, though EUR/SEK saw downside heading into the release, but this was short-lived as the SEK depreciated on the announcement; likely due to this being a one-off hike not the start of a cycle. Looking ahead, Nordea noted that while the Riksbank’s forecast is for rates to be left unchanged there is a risk they it be forced to introduce stimulus measures again; due to the credibility of their 2% inflation target coming under fire. Xper (XPER) and TiVo (TIVO) are to merge in an all-stock transaction which equates to a combined USD 3bln in enterprise value. The shares will be converted into shares of the new company based on a fixed exchange ratio of 0.455 XPER share per existing TIVO share.

* NORGES: Norges Bank left rates unchanged at 1.5% and the repo path was maintained at 1.6% for the entire forecast period. Given that there had been some expectations for a reduction in the forecast period, largely due to the downbeat regional network survey, the NOK did strengthen somewhat. Overall, the decision was as expected and indicates that the Norges Bank will most likely remain on-hold for the period ahead while retaining the possibility for a hike.

* BANXICO: The Mexican Central Bank cut rates by 25bps as expected by all analysts surveyed at Reuters. However, UBS had highlighted that a 50bp was not out of the question given the divided MPC, and with USDMXN beneath 19, virtual approval of the USMCA trade deal, US/China Trade ‘Phase One’ deal, and mitigating Brexit risks could all lean towards a 50bps cut, especially given inflation is at the mid-point of its 2-4% target range. However, the board was not as divided this time, where only 1 member opted for a 50bp cut taking its key rate to 7.00% (at its previous meeting, 2 members, Esquivel and Heath, voted for a 50bp cut). Banxico maintained its language that the current environment continues to present risks that could affect the macroeconomic conditions in the country and its potential for growth and maintained that balance of risks remain tilted to the downside in the uncertain environment. The Central Bank highlighted headline and core inflation in 2020 will reflect greater slack in the economy and higher than expected minimum wage hike, that could see inflation moderately above where it has been in the previous quarterly report; heading into the decision some had questioned whether the latest minimum wage hike combined with deeper easing would spur unnecessary upside to inflation. On Pemex, the board reiterated that uncertainty linked to credit ratings of PEMEX and sovereign persists, although previously Heath had stated that a possible credit rating downgrade for PEMEX was not a big risk to economic growth, but more of a risk to financial markets. Banxico concluded that although Q4 information is limited, it estimates that recent weakness persists. Given the expected cut and very similar statement, USDMXN was very much unreactive, however MXN slightly strengthened as only 1 member opted for a 50bp cut, although the moves were very short lived and it returned to pre-announcement levels.

* FX WRAP: DXY traded within 97.20 and 97.50 parameters today. The index ended the day rather flat but marginally lower today after it had a strong surge this week. Today’s mixed data put a cap to the gains following poor existing home sales, a mixed Philly-fed, and a rise in jobless claims for the week which feeds into the next payroll report. GBP continued to weaken as it breached 1.30 to the downside, with technicians eyeing 1.2984-76 as next key levels. Today’s weakness stemmed after a poor retail-sales, however the pre-Christmas period has had participants questioning the reliability of the report as the black-Friday/cyber week dates will be included in the next report. Selling was exacerbated heading into the BoE rate decision, however as the Central Bank kept to its script, some losses were reversed, perhaps as participants were expecting a more dovish outcome. AUD traded firmer after last night’s jobs report, albeit the large increase was driven by part time jobs. NZD also traded firmer amid a mixed Q3 GDP report and a narrower trade deficit. Riskbank hiked by 0.25bp as expected although two were against the move, although it confirmed that the move concludes policy normalisation and could provide more stimulus if needed. EURSEK traded relatively flat today, although at the time of the rate release the cross rose slightly amid the hike confirming it is a “one and done” move. Havens were generally firmer today, JPY was unphased by the latest BoJ rate decision, however gold traded marginally higher breaching 1480 briefly, a level it resides just shy of heading into Asia trade. In EMFX, USDMXN was unreactive following the latest Banxico rate decision, however very slight Peso strength was seen against the buck as this time, there was only one dissenter opting for a 50bp cut, down from two previously. USDMXN losses were short-lived and the cross traded around pre-announcement levels for the rest of the session still beneath the 19.00 handle, despite initially trading above it earlier this morning. USDTRY tested key Fib resistance after breaching October highs, largely shrugging off CBRT minutes as bullish technical and Lira negative geopolitical factors remain principle drivers. However, USDBRL held steady around 4.0600 as the BCB lifted GDP projections in its Q4 inflation report, although the cross is flat as the US session ends.

BANXICO PRIMER: Banxico are to release its latest interest rate decision on 19th December 2019 at 19:00 GMT/14:00 ET
content:
• The Mexican central bank is expected to cut rates by 25bp to 7.25%, which would be the fourth consecutive rate cut; all sixteen analysts surveyed by Reuters look for a 25bp cut.
  • PREVIOUS MEETING: At its last confab, the Banxico opted to lower rates by 25bps; however, two board members, Heath and Esquivel opted for a deeper 50bp cut. The latest minutes revealed that the majority of members said the growth outlook had continued to deteriorate, noting that it was facing risks to inflation, and that monetary policy would be adjusted in a firm and opportune manner. Banxico tends to follow a similar footing to the US Federal Reserve, although now the Fed is on hold; Banxico previously has stated that although it monitors the Fed, it is not a direct determinant for its monetary policy decisions.
  • 25BPS CUT: Although inflation is in line with its target, the core measure is running at 3.7% (the Banxico’s target range is 2-4%), while the recent 20% rise to the minimum wage has given rise to some concerns that further easing might result in unnecessary upside to inflation. Another reason against a deeper 50bps cut is that Banxico may not want to shock markets , thus maintaining its easing bias at a gradual pace; the latest minutes signalled a majority believe an adjustment to monetary policy should be gradual. TD Securities believes a 50bps cut would be too aggressive, noting that “the relatively unleveraged nature of Mexico's economy dulls the growth-positive impact of cuts, while net negative fixed income flows over the past 6 months currently render MXN vulnerable.”
  • A DEEPER CUT? Despite all analysts looking for a 25bps cut, analysts at UBS (who are in line with the consensus) highlights that a 50bps move is not out of the question, given the divided MPC, and with USDMXN beneath 19, virtual approval of the USMCA trade deal, US/China Trade ‘Phase One’ deal, and mitigating Brexit risks could all lean towards a 50bps cut, especially given inflation is at the mid-point of its 2-4% target range. UBS believes that if a 50bps cut is seen, Banxico will signal towards less aggressive easing ahead.
  • PEMEX: In its latest meeting, the Banxico maintained its language that uncertainty persists to the credit rating outlook for Pemex and Mexico’s sovereign debt. However, the dovish board member Heath stated that the possible credit rating downgrade for PEMEX was not a big risk to its economic growth, but it was more of a risk to financial markets.

Daily FX Wrap: Sterling turns full circle ahead of Friday’s WA/transition bill
content:
GBP

A week can be a long time in politics, but not always for the Pound it seems as Cable continues its retreat from post-election exit poll high and Eur/Gbp rebounds further from Conservative majority low. In fact, the former is now under GE day lows and almost 5 big figures down from 1.3500+ highs, while the cross has completed a round trip from sub-0.8300 to just over 0.8500 in the same period. The catalyst, not bleak pre-Xmas UK retail sales, flat CBI distributive trades or an unchanged and still mostly Brexit dependent BoE, but concerns about no deal with the EU after December 2020 if PM Johnson succeeds in getting a further extension blocked alongside the vote on his WAB tomorrow.

USD

The DXY remains relatively rangebound between 97.000-500 after another attempt to breach the topside was thwarted by disappointing US data, including weekly claims, existing home sales and the LEI, and a somewhat mixed Philly Fed survey. However, the Greenback derived some underlying support at the expense of others and a steeper US Treasury curve amidst increasingly thin seasonal volumes and Fed dove Bullard giving his backing for no further policy adjustments next year.

AUD/NOK

The Aussie was bid from the outset and outperforming in wake of an upbeat labour report that prompted a marked shift in RBA rate (cut) expectations for February 2020, but the Norwegian Crown has emerged as the best major following the last Norges Bank policy meeting of the current year and updated depo rate projections that infer a 10 bp hike in 2022. Aud/Usd still bid within 0.6883-49 parameters, while Eur/Nok hovers near the base of a 10.0210-9.9575 band.

JPY/CHF

The safe-havens have benefited from the Dollar’s inability to break higher, as noted above, rather than any real or significant downturn in risk sentiment, but the Yen has bounced more firmly from 109.60+ lows through 108.50 and not far from chart resistance in the 109.20-30 zone, while the Franc has consolidated recovery gains beyond 0.9800 and 1.0900 vs the Euro.

NZD/SEK

Choppy trade for the Kiwi and Swedish Krona following mixed NZ Q3 GDP metrics and a pronounced revision to q/q growth in the previous quarter, while the Riksbank stuck to its script and tightened by ¼ point despite 2 dissentions, but effectively confirmed that the move concludes policy normalisation and it could provide more stimulus if needed. Usd/Nzd nestling just shy of 0.6600 vs Eur/Sek towards the top of 10.4920-4450 extremes.

EUR/CAD

The single currency and Loonie have both gradually lost momentum vs their US counterpart, as Eur/Usd faded ahead of 1.1150 and Usd/Cad waned on approach to 1.3100 following considerably worse than forecast Canadian wholesale trade data.

EM

Usd/Try has tested key Fib resistance after breaching October highs, largely shrugging off CBRT minutes as bullish technical and Lira negative geopolitical factors remain principle drivers. However, Usd/Brl held steady around 4.0600 as the BCB lifted GDP projections in its Q4 inflation report and Usd/Rub remained lower circa 62.3500 amidst firm oil prices and reports of shootings in Moscow close to the FSB HQ.

content:
INDIVIDUAL STOCK MOVERS

Gainers

  • Conagra Brands (CAG) +13.5% following its earnings report which beat on EPS and revenues were in line with expectations, the co. also cut its FY20 EPS forecast, although the cut was not as deep as analysts were expecting. CAG also expect strong performance in H2 2020. 
  • Centene (CNC) +4% after The Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the ruling that the Affordable Care Act’s individual mandate is unconstitutional but sent the case back to reconsider. JP Morgan and Oppenheimer both highlight the Circuit Court of Appeals “tweener” ruling was in line with expectations. Oppenheimer highlight the Affordable Care Act isn’t going anywhere any time soon, and JP Morgan note Centene (CNC) and Molina Healthcare (MOH) have by far the greatest earnings exposure to the ACA.
  • Micron (MU) +2.5% after its earnings which were in line and guided lower than expected for Q2, however the co. signaled a bottoming out of its financial performance in Q2, whilst its 8-k filing also removed the mention of it being mindful of macroeconomic and trade uncertainties. 

Losers

  • Darden Restaurants (DRI) -3.9% after its Q2 SSS missed expectations printing 2.0%, 0.1% beneath expectations. 
  • Fleetcor Tech (FLT) -3.6% after it announced negotiations with the FTC are at an impasse, however it also announced an accelerated share repurchase programme which would be financed through a mixture of cash and debt.
  • Uber (UBER) -0.7%  after it had its Uber rental car services in Germany banned by a Frankfurt court
analysis_details: • The three major US indices opened marginally higher once again this week just shy of all time intra-day highs and just beneath the key psychological 3200 level. Gains appear to be driven by stock specific stories with the Nasdaq marginally outperforming its two US counterparts being led by gains in Netflix (NFLX) following a positive mention at Goldman Sachs. Micron (MU) also performing well after it signaled a bottoming out of its financial performance in Q2 after its Q1 results, which also gave a boost to other semiconductor names such as Western Digital (WDC). In sectors, Consumer Staples lead the way today following strong earnings from Conagra Brands (CAG), who trade higher by 13% at the open. Communication Services also performing well after strong performance in NFLX. On the flipside, Consumer Discretionary are flat/lower following poor earnings from Darden Resorts (DRI), and General Motors (GM), who are lower after it issued a safety recall for 900k vehicles.

BoE December Minutes Summary: MPC votes 7-2 (Exp. 7-2) in favour of maintaining rates at 0.75% - Haskel and Saunders voted in favour of a 25bps cut
content:
Vote split on the base rate: MPC votes 7-2 to stand pat on rates at 0.75%

Vote split on corporate bonds: MPC votes 9-0 to maintain the stock of corporate bonds at GBP 10bln

Vote split on APF: MPC votes 9-0 to maintain the stock of UK government bond purchases at GBP 435bln

Rate guidance: MPC reiterates that monetary policy could respond in either direction in order to hit its inflation target. Monetary policy could be required if global growth fails to stabilise and Brexit uncertainties remain entrenched. However, should these risks not materialise and the economy performs broadly in-line with the MPC’s projection, gradual and limited rate rises could be needed.

Brexit: MPC recaps the assumptions of the November MPR that there will be an orderly transition to a deep free trade agreement between the UK and the EU.

Overview: Since the previous meeting, economic data have been broadly inline with the November report. The partial de-escalation of the US-China trade war provides some additional support to the outlook, relative to November.

Domestic growth: Q3 GDP printed at 0.3% and is expected to come in at 0.1% in Q4. Household consumption has continued to grow steadily, but business investment and export orders remain weak.

Inflation: CPI remained at 1.5% in November and core CPI remained at 1.7%, broadly as expected. MPC reiterates that the headline rate is expected to fall to around 1.25% by the spring, owing to the temporary effects of falls in regulated energy and water prices.

Labour market: There have been some signs that the labour market has been loosening, although it remains tight and employment growth is around its record high.
reaction_details:
• In an immediate reaction to the unchanged rate decision, where Saunders and Haskel once again dissented (favoured a 25bp cut, however there were some analysts expectations for a 3rd dissenter) and the BoE noted that should the economy perform broadly in-line with MPC projection then gradual and limited hikes may be required; as such, these slightly hawkish notes have provided some support to GBP in-light of the more dovish expectations going into the meeting.
  • Although, the BoE did include a more dovish statement around business investment and export orders, noting they remain weak

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 19th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities trade lacklustre amid a lack of fresh fundamental catalysts in holiday-thinned trade
  • US House voted to impeach President Trump under Article 1 (Abuse of Power) and Article 2 (Obstruction of Congress); as expected
  • BoJ kept monetary policy settings were left unchanged, Riksbank hiked, Norges stood pat – all as expected
  • Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries have all extended losses and remain under pressure
  • Looking ahead, highlights include BoE policy announcement, US Philadelphia Fed, Weekly Jobs, Existing Home Sales, ECB’s Lane

TRADE

China announces new tariffs exclusions for some US products, exemptions apply to six new US products - effective from Dec 26th 2019 to Dec 25th 2020, according to Xinhua. (Xinhua)

China MOFCOM says US and Chinese trade teams are maintaining close communication regarding the signing of the Phase One deal. China Global Times highlights that MOFCOM refrained from confirming if the Phase One trade deal will be signed in January as suggested by some US officials. (Twitter/Newswires)

US President Trump said we made a great deal with China which gives us a lot of currency to do the phase 2 deal. There were also separate comments from NEC Director Kudlow who suggested the US will monitor China compliance over 6 to 9 months, while Kudlow reportedly stated that Chinese President Xi told Henry Kissinger he would rather deal with President Trump who will focus more on trade rather than Democrats who won't talk about trade issues but instead will focus on human rights and other things. (Newswires/CNBC/Twitter)

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were lacklustre following an indecisive lead from US where the major indices finished flat due to a lack of drivers amid the pre-holiday lull. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was subdued by weakness in energy and the top-weighted financials sector, with early gains in the index wiped out after better than expected jobs data dampened February rate cut hopes, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) continued its marginal pullback from the 24k level amid a choppy currency and after a lack of fireworks at the BoJ policy meeting. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch) traded indecisively and failed to take advantage of another substantial liquidity effort by the PBoC as well as expectations it may fine tune measures and use targeted stimulus next year, with some reports suggesting China’s private enterprises are facing the worst funding squeeze in more than two decades. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower and prices eyed a test on the 152.00 level to the downside with demand subdued alongside an uneventful BoJ policy announcement where the central bank maintained all policy settings as expected and reiterated its forward guidance that rates will remain at current or lower levels for as long as needed.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 250bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 7.0025 vs. Exp. 6.9987 (Prev. 6.9969)

 

US  

US House voted (230 vs. 197) to impeach President Trump under Article 1 Abuse of Power and voted (229 vs. 198) to impeach President Trump under Article 2 Obstruction of Congress as expected. The White House released a statement shortly after in which it noted that President Trump is prepared for the next steps and is confident he will be fully exonerated at the Senate trial. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

BoJ kept monetary policy settings unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.1% and 10yr JGB yield target at around 0%, while it maintained forward guidance that rates will remain at current or lower levels for as long as needed to guard against risk momentum for hitting price target may be lost. BoJ repeated its assessment that Japan's economy is expanding moderately as a trend but cut the assessment on industrial production in which it states industrial output is falling due to impact of natural disasters. BoJ later announced plans decided in April to lend ETFs to markets under a special facility aimed at improving liquidity in the ETF market, while it will amend the scheme aimed at encouraging banks to increase lending and will allow borrowers to roll over lending under certain conditions. (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said overseas risks remain at high levels and warrants attention, appropriate to guide policy with easing bias, BoJ's NIRP is appropriate, deepening negative rates would an option but cannot cut indefinitely as it would affect banks. (Newswires)

Riksbank hiked its Repo Rate by 25bps to 0.00%, as expected. Forecast for repo rate is unchanged, repo rate is expected to remain at 0% in the coming years. Deputy governors Breman and Jansson entered reservations against the rate hike. Improved prospects would justify a higher interest rate. But if the economy were instead to develop more weakly than forecast, the Executive Board could both cut the repo rate and take other measures to make monetary policy more expansionary. (Newswires)

Norges Bank left its Key Policy Rate unchanged at 1.50%, as expected in a unanimous decision. Norges Bank left its rate path unchanged for 2020 and 2021 but upgraded 2022 to 1.60% from 1.50%. Norges noted that monetary stance has become less expansionary and a weaker-than-projected krone implies in isolation a higher policy rate path, whilst on the other hand, the upturn in the Norwegian economy appears to be a little more moderate than previously assumed. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

SGH Macro have stated that from what they understand, the EU Commission will formally restart negotiations with the UK on 1st February and believes the Commission “already has in its desk drawers a draft trade agreement for Whitehall to weigh and potentially adopt with limited changes, and which could be moved fairly quickly”. (SGH Macro)

UK State Opening of Parliament will begin today with a speech at 11:40GMT, read by the Queen but written by the Government which will outline the Conservative’s agenda for the year. (BBC)

SNP Leader Sturgeon will publish a ‘detailed case’ for a second independence referendum, and will ask for a power transfer to ensure any vote is legal. UK Government are opposed to second referendum. (BBC)

UK PM Johnson is said to be planning to reduce rates for small businesses. (Daily Mail)

UK Retail Sales MM (Nov) -0.6% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. -0.1%)

German debt agency says Federal government plans to issue EUR 210bln of debt in 2020 ex-linkers. (Newswires) 

EQUITIES

A mostly uninspiring session for European bourses thus far [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.1%] – following on from a similarly lacklustre Asia-Pac session. Sectors are flat/mixed with defensives modestly firmer vs. their cyclical peers, with the exception of energy names who remain buoyed by yesterday’s advances in the complex. Individual stocks stories remain in focus given the lack of fresh macro catalysts. The IT sector failed to capitalise on optimistic earnings from Micron (+4.1% pre-market) late doors yesterday with STMicroelectronics (+0.3%), Micro Focus (-0.1%) and Dialog Semiconductor (-0.1%) all relatively unfazed. Elsewhere, NMC Health (-9.8%) has wiped out yesterday’s gains as the negative note from activist short-seller Muddy Waters continues to cause concern around the Co’s balance sheet. Swatch (-1.2%) and Richemont (-1.4%) are weighed on by a 3.5% YY decline in Swiss watch exports. In terms of other individual movers, Hugo Boss (-2.4%), Capita (-4.2%), TUI (-1.9%) trade near the foot of the Stoxx 600 amid negative broker action.

FX

AUD/NOK - The Aussie and Norwegian Krona are vying for pole position on the G10 grid following better than expected jobs data overnight and a final 2019 Norges Bank policy meeting that was fractionally less dovish than anticipated. Aud/Usd is back within striking distance of 0.6900, albeit off highs and hovering close to a decent option expiry at 0.6875 (1.1 bn), while Eur/Nok has maintained momentum under the psychological 10.0000 level and got close to support from early October (circa 9.9460) as the CB tweaked is rate path to flag 10 bp worth of tightening in 2022.

GBP/EUR - The next best majors or beneficiaries of a flagging Dollar, as the DXY drifts down from a 97.421 high to just shy of 97.250, with Cable able to reclaim 1.3100+ status even though UK retail sales fell far short of consensus and the single currency pivots 1.1125 amidst firmer Eurozone bond yields alongside another rise in market-based inflation expectations. Back to the Pound, perhaps some underlying impetus from reports that the EU already has a trade proposal in hand for the UK to consider a day after Brexit on January 31 next year, but more immediately CBI trades loom before the BoE at high noon with the focus on any further dovish dissent or a more united MPC in wake of the election.

JPY/CAD/CHF/NZD - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, as Usd/Jpy continues meander above 109.50 and the Yen gleans little fresh direction from the BoJ keeping policy unchanged and an easing bias, while Usd/Cad hovers in a tight band on the 1.3100 handle ahead of Canadian AWE and wholesale trade data. Elsewhere, Usd/Chf is still straddling 0.9800 with the Franc not really responding to a wider Swiss trade surplus as key watch exports fell, and similarly Nzd/Usd failed to get any lasting or clear impetus from NZ GDP data for Q3 as firmer than forecast q/q growth was offset by a y/y miss sharp downgrade to the former for the previous quarter.

SEK - The Swedish Crown has been choppy between 10.4450-10.4805 parameters in wake of the Riksbank’s last hurrah for the year as a clearly signalled 25 bp repo rate hike was duly delivered, but not without 2 Board members voting against the move and with the accompanying statement caveated by the pledge to ease if the economy does not meet target.

EM - Yet more pain for the Turkish Lira, as Usd/Try extended further to the upside through mid-October peaks and the high for that month overall before fading a fraction below Fib resistance awaiting CBRT minutes and unfolding Turkish-US developments on the diplomatic front.

Australian Employment Change (Nov) 39.9k vs. Exp. 14.0k (Prev. -19.0k, Rev. -24.8k). (Newswires) Australian Unemployment Rate (Nov) 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.3% (Prev. 5.3%) Australian Full Time Employment Change (Nov) 4.2k (Prev. -10.3k, Rev. -10.5k) Australian Part Time Employment Change (Nov) 35.7k (Prev. -8.7k, Rev. -14.3k)

New Zealand GDP (Q3) Q/Q 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%, Rev. 0.1%). (Newswires) New Zealand GDP (Q3) Y/Y 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.1%)

FIXED INCOME

Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries have all extended losses and are still under pressure as the former dangles just above 171.00, UK equivalent sits within a few ticks of 131.30 and latter crosses 128-00.  Seasonal trading conditions are exacerbating price action, though that applies both ways and the current tone/trend is bearish with deeper and potentially more pivotal downside chart targets in close proximity. Hence, the path of least resistance could literally be lower barring something major on the fundamental side that may change the technical landscape, like Thursday’s run of US data or ECB’s Lane.

COMMODITIES 

WTI and Brent futures remain flat within relatively narrow intraday parameters following the EIA-led upside seen across the complex yesterday. The former resides just under the USD 61/bbl mark, having traded on either side of its 100 WMA (USD 60.77/bbl) throughout APAC hours, while its Brent counterpart remains afloat above the USD 66/bbl mark after testing, but failing to breach support at the round figure overnight. Crude markets have seen little by way of fresh fundamental catalysts in recent days heading into the holiday period, albeit traders will be on the lookout for more “meat on the bones” regarding the China Phase One deal, given the lack of details post-announcement. That said, the thinned market conditions may prompt volatility in energy prices even with a lack of news-flow. Elsewhere, spot gold trades with mild losses and currently resides below the USD 1475/oz mark having dipping below its 50 DMA USD 1477.20/oz with technicians eyeing USD 1470-71/oz for potential support ahead if the 21 DMA at USD 1467.20/oz. Copper prices remain unchanged intraday below the USD 2.8/lb level given the tentative tone around the marketplace. Finally, Shanghai aluminium prices rose to their highest level in over three months and notched a third straight session of gains amid depleting stocks of the metal in Chinese warehouses.

subject: Newsquawk EU Mid Session: Five down, one to go and multiple US data releases - 19th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

A mostly uninspiring session for European bourses thus far [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.1%] – following on from a similarly lacklustre Asia-Pac session. Sectors are flat/mixed with defensives modestly firmer vs. their cyclical peers, with the exception of energy names who remain buoyed by yesterday’s advances in the complex. Individual stocks stories remain in focus given the lack of fresh macro catalysts. The IT sector failed to capitalise on optimistic earnings from Micron (+4.1% pre-market) late doors yesterday with STMicroelectronics (+0.3%), Micro Focus (-0.1%) and Dialog Semiconductor (-0.1%) all relatively unfazed. Elsewhere, NMC Health (-9.8%) has wiped out yesterday’s gains as the negative note from activist short-seller Muddy Waters continues to cause concern around the Co’s balance sheet. Swatch (-1.2%) and Richemont (-1.4%) are weighed on by a 3.5% YY decline in Swiss watch exports. In terms of other individual movers, Hugo Boss (-2.4%), Capita (-4.2%), TUI (-1.9%) trade near the foot of the Stoxx 600 amid negative broker action.

FX

AUD/NOK - The Aussie and Norwegian Krona are vying for pole position on the G10 grid following better than expected jobs data overnight and a final 2019 Norges Bank policy meeting that was fractionally less dovish than anticipated. Aud/Usd is back within striking distance of 0.6900, albeit off highs and hovering close to a decent option expiry at 0.6875 (1.1 bn), while Eur/Nok has maintained momentum under the psychological 10.0000 level and got close to support from early October (circa 9.9460) as the CB tweaked is rate path to flag 10 bp worth of tightening in 2022.

GBP/EUR - The next best majors or beneficiaries of a flagging Dollar, as the DXY drifts down from a 97.421 high to just shy of 97.250, with Cable able to reclaim 1.3100+ status even though UK retail sales fell far short of consensus and the single currency pivots 1.1125 amidst firmer Eurozone bond yields alongside another rise in market-based inflation expectations. Back to the Pound, perhaps some underlying impetus from reports that the EU already has a trade proposal in hand for the UK to consider a day after Brexit on January 31 next year, but more immediately CBI trades loom before the BoE at high noon with the focus on any further dovish dissent or a more united MPC in wake of the election.

JPY/CAD/CHF/NZD - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, as Usd/Jpy continues meander above 109.50 and the Yen gleans little fresh direction from the BoJ keeping policy unchanged and an easing bias, while Usd/Cad hovers in a tight band on the 1.3100 handle ahead of Canadian AWE and wholesale trade data. Elsewhere, Usd/Chf is still straddling 0.9800 with the Franc not really responding to a wider Swiss trade surplus as key watch exports fell, and similarly Nzd/Usd failed to get any lasting or clear impetus from NZ GDP data for Q3 as firmer than forecast q/q growth was offset by a y/y miss sharp downgrade to the former for the previous quarter.

SEK - The Swedish Crown has been choppy between 10.4450-10.4805 parameters in wake of the Riksbank’s last hurrah for the year as a clearly signalled 25 bp repo rate hike was duly delivered, but not without 2 Board members voting against the move and with the accompanying statement caveated by the pledge to ease if the economy does not meet target.

EM - Yet more pain for the Turkish Lira, as Usd/Try extended further to the upside through mid-October peaks and the high for that month overall before fading a fraction below Fib resistance awaiting CBRT minutes and unfolding Turkish-US developments on the diplomatic front.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries have all extended losses and are still under pressure as the former dangles just above 171.00, UK equivalent sits within a few ticks of 131.30 and latter crosses 128-00.  Seasonal trading conditions are exacerbating price action, though that applies both ways and the current tone/trend is bearish with deeper and potentially more pivotal downside chart targets in close proximity. Hence, the path of least resistance could literally be lower barring something major on the fundamental side that may change the technical landscape, like Thursday’s run of US data or ECB’s Lane.

COMMODITIES 

WTI and Brent futures remain flat within relatively narrow intraday parameters following the EIA-led upside seen across the complex yesterday. The former resides just under the USD 61/bbl mark, having traded on either side of its 100 WMA (USD 60.77/bbl) throughout APAC hours, while its Brent counterpart remains afloat above the USD 66/bbl mark after testing, but failing to breach support at the round figure overnight. Crude markets have seen little by way of fresh fundamental catalysts in recent days heading into the holiday period, albeit traders will be on the lookout for more “meat on the bones” regarding the China Phase One deal, given the lack of details post-announcement. That said, the thinned market conditions may prompt volatility in energy prices even with a lack of news-flow. Elsewhere, spot gold trades with mild losses and currently resides below the USD 1475/oz mark having dipping below its 50 DMA USD 1477.20/oz with technicians eyeing USD 1470-71/oz for potential support ahead if the 21 DMA at USD 1467.20/oz. Copper prices remain unchanged intraday below the USD 2.8/lb level given the tentative tone around the marketplace. Finally, Shanghai aluminium prices rose to their highest level in over three months and notched a third straight session of gains amid depleting stocks of the metal in Chinese warehouses.

Gilt and Short Sterling futures on the defensive ahead of data, CBI and BoE
content: The 10 year UK benchmark has been choppy in early Liffe trade, partly in line with debt peers, but also maintaining relatively close inverse correlations with the Pound that has managed to claw back some losses in FX circles. Gilts survived an initial assault on yesterday’s session base after opening at 131.64, but the recovery was fleeting/tame and the 2nd attempt to flush out bids/stops and intraday longs was successful as 131.63 gave way. However, 131.50 just about held and the bond is off worst levels within a 131.77-52 early range awaiting ONS retail sales, CBI distributive trades and then the BoE at high noon, while the 3 month strip is 0.5 to 1.5 ticks adrift vs -1 to -2 ticks at the lows.

content: It’s been another relatively slow grind, but no less compelling from a technical perspective and with volumes picking up ahead of the EU cash bourse opens, as the 10 year German debt future breached Fib support at 171.39 before declining through Wednesday’s Eurex low to trade down at 171.19. Naturally, the 171.00 handle appears alluring and would push the benchmark yield closer towards -20 bp, but the core Eurozone bond has pared some losses more recently.

19th December 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were lacklustre following an indecisive lead from US where the major indices finished flat due to a lack of drivers amid the pre-holiday lull. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was subdued by weakness in energy and the top-weighted financials sector, with early gains in the index wiped out after better than expected jobs data dampened February rate cut hopes, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) continued its marginal pullback from the 24k level amid a choppy currency and after a lack of fireworks at the BoJ policy meeting. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) traded indecisive and failed to take advantage of another substantial liquidity effort by the PBoC as well as expectations it may fine tune measures and use targeted stimulus next year, with some reports suggesting China’s private enterprises are facing the worst funding squeeze in more than two decades.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 19th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were lacklustre following an indecisive lead from US where the major indices finished flat due to a lack of drivers
  • BoJ kept monetary policy settings unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.1% and 10yr JGB yield target at around 0%, maintained forward guidance
  • US House voted to impeach President Trump under Article 1 (Abuse of Power) and Article 2 (Obstruction of Congress); as expected
  • AUD/USD was boosted by better than expected Employment data, although the gains were predominantly fuelled by part-time jobs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Riksbank, Norges Bank, BoE policy announcements, UK Retail Sales, US Philadelphia Fed, Weekly Jobs, Existing Home Sales, ECB’s Lane

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were lacklustre following an indecisive lead from US where the major indices finished flat due to a lack of drivers amid the pre-holiday lull. ASX 200 (-0.3%) was subdued by weakness in energy and the top-weighted financials sector, with early gains in the index wiped out after better than expected jobs data dampened February rate cut hopes, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) continued its marginal pullback from the 24k level amid a choppy currency and after a lack of fireworks at the BoJ policy meeting. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) traded indecisively and failed to take advantage of another substantial liquidity effort by the PBoC as well as expectations it may fine tune measures and use targeted stimulus next year, with some reports suggesting China’s private enterprises are facing the worst funding squeeze in more than two decades. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower and prices eyed a test on the 152.00 level to the downside with demand subdued alongside an uneventful BoJ policy announcement where the central bank maintained all policy settings as expected and reiterated its forward guidance that rates will remain at current or lower levels for as long as needed.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 250bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 7.0025 vs. Exp. 6.9987 (Prev. 6.9969)

China announces new tariffs exclusions for some US products, exemptions apply to six new US products - effective from Dec 26th 2019 to Dec 25th 2020, according to Xinhua. (Xinhua)

US President Trump said we made a great deal with China which gives us a lot of currency to do the phase 2 deal. There were also separate comments from NEC Director Kudlow who suggested the US will monitor China compliance over 6 to 9 months, while Kudlow reportedly stated that Chinese President Xi told Henry Kissinger he would rather deal with President Trump who will focus more on trade rather than Democrats who won't talk about trade issues but instead will focus on human rights and other things. (Newswires/CNBC/Twitter)

BoJ kept monetary policy settings unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.1% and 10yr JGB yield target at around 0%, while it maintained forward guidance that rates will remain at current or lower levels for as long as needed to guard against risk momentum for hitting price target may be lost. BoJ repeated its assessment that Japan's economy is expanding moderately as a trend but cut the assessment on industrial production in which it states industrial output is falling due to impact of natural disasters. BoJ later announced plans decided in April to lend ETFs to markets under a special facility aimed at improving liquidity in the ETF market, while it will amend the scheme aimed at encouraging banks to increase lending and will allow borrowers to roll over lending under certain conditions. (Newswires)

UK/EU

SGH Macro have stated that from what they understand, the EU Commission will formally restart negotiations with the UK on 1st February and believes the Commission “already has in its desk drawers a draft trade agreement for Whitehall to weigh and potentially adopt with limited changes, and which could be moved fairly quickly”. (SGH Macro)

 

UK State Opening of Parliament will begin today with a speech at 11:40GMT, read by the Queen but written by the Government which will outline the Conservative’s agenda for the year. (BBC)

 

SNP Leader Sturgeon will publish a ‘detailed case’ for a second independence referendum, and will ask for a power transfer to ensure any vote is legal. UK Government are opposed to second referendum. (BBC)

 

UK PM Johnson is said to be planning to reduce rates for small businesses. (Daily Mail) 

FX 

DXY was only minimally pressured overnight after the House officially impeached US President Trump under both articles regarding Abuse of Power and Obstruction of Congress as expected, and which sets up a showdown at the Senate where it is seen as unlikely to pass and would require a two-thirds majority to convict the President and remove him from office vs. the simple majority that was needed in the Democrat-controlled House. This provided some mild reprieve to the greenback’s transatlantic counterparts to build upon a rebound in EUR/USD from its recent floor at 1.1110 and GBP/USD also partially benefitted but remained at a sub-1.3100 level with price action contained by the recent Brexit-cliff fears and ahead of the upcoming BoE meeting. Elsewhere, antipodeans were data driven in which NZD/USD briefly surged after Q3 GDP Q/Q topped estimates but with the gains short-lived as GDP Y/Y missed, while AUD/USD was boosted by better than expected Employment data and a surprise decline in the Unemployment Rate to 5.2% from 5.3% and although the gains were predominantly fuelled by Part-Time jobs, it still led to a drop in the market pricing for an RBA rate cut in February to 38% from over 50%. The Aussie jobs data also lifted AUD/JPY which USD/JPY was quick to piggyback on, although moves in the latter were eventually faded as attention turned to the BoJ decision which proved to be a non-event. 

Australian Employment Change (Nov) 39.9k vs. Exp. 14.0k (Prev. -19.0k, Rev. -24.8k). (Newswires) Australian Unemployment Rate (Nov) 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.3% (Prev. 5.3%) Australian Full Time Employment Change (Nov) 4.2k (Prev. -10.3k, Rev. -10.5k) Australian Part Time Employment Change (Nov) 35.7k (Prev. -8.7k, Rev. -14.3k)

New Zealand GDP (Q3) Q/Q 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.5%, Rev. 0.1%). (Newswires) New Zealand GDP (Q3) Y/Y 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.1%)

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded lacklustre in which WTI crude future pulled back from USD 61.00/bbl and gave up some of the prior session’s gains which had been spurred after this week’s EIA inventory report showed a narrower than expected draw but was still at a sharp contrast to surprise build in API stockpiles, while the subdued picture across the complex was mostly a function of the pre-holiday lull seen across global markets. Elsewhere, gold was rangebound but remained afloat on the miniscule pressure for the greenback after President Trump became the 3rd President in history to be impeached by the House, and copper prices continued to meander around the USD 2.80/lb amid the dampened risk tone.  

US 

T-Notes moved lower alongside the Bund on Wednesday as participants sold duration, with risk appetite remaining elevated in the final few weeks of the year. Some have noted that while activity is winding down for the year, one desk noted a couple of themes still in play: there is still interest in curve steepeners, as seen over the last week or so, particularly with accounts adding to 2s10s; another theme that is clear is the selling of volatility, both in Europe and the US, with the desk noting that the selling came despite the recent fall in implied volatility in both Treasuries and Bunds. "One area where flows have remained fairly strong is the option market," the strategist said, "perhaps some think the drop off in vol has gone too far," and notes that "the moves over last Christmas perhaps prompted some to position for a repeat, when vol spiked in both fixed income and equities". T-note (H0) futures settled 9 ticks lower at 128-05+.

US House voted (230 vs. 197) to impeach President Trump under Article 1 Abuse of Power and voted (229 vs. 198) to impeach President Trump under Article 2 Obstruction of Congress as expected. The White House released a statement shortly after in which it noted that President Trump is prepared for the next steps and is confident he will be fully exonerated at the Senate trial. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (2020 Non-Voter, Dove) said the US labour market is vibrant and the economy is doing "remarkably well", while he suggested that monetary policy is at a good setting currently and it’s a good time to watch the data. Furthermore, Evans added it would take a lot of new data to change his opinion and inflation would need to go meaningfully above 2% for him to support monetary tightening. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawkish) believes we are in a reasonable place on the balance sheet and that policy is still accommodative, while he added that he is very focused on data and that it is hard to find evidence of deteriorating credit quality at the moment, but the Fed is watching the data. (Newswires)

content: Asia equity markets were lacklustre following an indecisive lead from US where the major indices finished flat due to a lack of drivers amid the pre-holiday lull. (-0.2%) traded indecisive and failed to take advantage of another substantial liquidity effort by the PBoC as well as expectations it may fine tune measures and use targeted stimulus next year, with some reports suggesting China’s private enterprises are facing the worst funding squeeze in more than two decades. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower and prices eyed a test on the 152.00 level to the downside with demand subdued alongside an uneventful BoJ policy announcement where the central bank maintained all policy settings as expected and reiterated its forward guidance that rates will remain at current or lower levels for as long as needed.

content:

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Global pre-holiday lull keeps Asia stocks lacklustre
content:
Asia equity markets trade lacklustre following an indecisive lead from US where the major indices finished flat due to a lack of drivers in pre-holiday lull trade. ASX 200 (-0.2%) is subdued by weakness in energy and the top-weighted financials sector, with early gains in the index wiped out after better than expected jobs data dampened February rate cut hopes, while the Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) continues its marginal pullback from the 24k level amid a choppy currency. Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) are indecisive and have failed to take advantage of another substantial liquidity effort by the PBoC as well as expectations it may fine tune measures and use targeted stimulus next year, with some reports suggesting China’s private enterprises are facing the worst funding squeeze in more than two decades.

In FX markets, the DXY has seen minimal pressure overnight after the House officially impeached US President Trump under both articles regarding Abuse of Power and Obstruction of Congress, which was as expected and sets up a showdown at the Senate where it is seen as unlikely to pass and would require a two-thirds majority to convict the President and remove him from office vs. the simple majority that was needed in the Democrat-controlled House. This provided some mild reprieve to the greenback’s transatlantic counterparts to build upon a rebound in EUR/USD from its recent floor at 1.1110 and GBP/USD also partially benefits but remains at a sub-1.3100 level with price action contained by the recent Brexit-cliff fears and ahead of the upcoming BoE meeting. Elsewhere, antipodeans were data driven with NZD/USD briefly surging after Q3 GDP Q/Q topped estimates at 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.6% but with the gains short-lived as GDP Y/Y missed at 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.4%, while AUD/USD was boosted by better than expected jobs data and a surprise decline in the Unemployment Rate to 5.2% from 5.3% and although the gains in Employment were predominantly fuelled by Part-Time jobs, it still led to a drop in the market pricing for an RBA rate cut in February to 38% from over 50%. The Aussie jobs data lifted AUD/JPY which USD/JPY was quick to piggyback on although gains in the latter were eventually faded as attention turns to the looming BoJ announcement.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower with prices eyeing the 152.00 level to the downside as participants are sidelined ahead of the BoJ policy announcement where no major fireworks are expected.

subject: US House begins voting on first of 2 articles of impeachment against US President Trump
analysis_details:
The House requires a simple majority (51%) to adopt the articles. If either article is adopted, then President Trump will be impeached.

If Trump is impeached, then the President will be tried in the Republican-controlled Senate. The Senate would require a two-thirds majority (67%) to convict the President and remove him from office – a scenario seen as almost impossible, judging from remarks of Republican Senators.

Accordingly, while the impeachment proceedings will generate a lot of column inches, it is likely that the market impact will be minimal for now, analysts believe.
